howard's campus is in the heart of d.c., which is not a good neighborhood at all. the campus is open, which means it is not shut off and anyone can come on campus at anytime.
howard is where greek life started. the organizations are filled with pride and are always displaying their talents.

there are so many social groups and clubs to be involved in. these include clubs for almost every state, belief, interest and sports. our sporting events are extremely fun due to the large amount of school spirit howard students have.

howard is great for cultured people and people who money is not an issue for. please understand: if money is an issue in any way, howard is not the place for you and you will have a constant stress on your shoulders.

howard is an h.b.c.u., which means there are a wide variety of traditions that honor black people. these include singing the negro national anthem at sporting events and the greek life chanting and dancing any chance they get.

the cost of howard university is huge, but it seems as if the school is always asking for more money. nothing is free, and what you pay for, is bad service from staff, mediocre food, and housing with constant issues.

honestly, there is not much to do for fun at howard unless you have money to spend. most college students struggle with finances. and there are not a lot of free events or things to do at howard. if you have the means to venture out in dc, there are common city past-times such as movie theaters and shopping. parties are usually at clubs, which can cost over $20.

the food served in the two cafeteria is bearable. nothing can compare to home, but there is always something that students can find enjoyable. the hours of operation of the only dining places on campus are very limited and inconvenient.

housing is a huge pain. howard has more students then they can accommodate. therefore housing is not guaranteed. the dorms have many issues including frequent electrical outages, false fire alarms, and the lack of hot water.
this varies depending on individual majors. there is always a way to get help when needed.

i beg you all to apply for so many scholarships. howard is an extremely expensive school, and the staff could care less about their students if money is an issue. howard will not be an enjoyable experience if there is money that needs to be paid.
howard has many negatives but is a great experience. i rate howard university on a scale from 1-10 with 10 being the best, a 7. a lot of the bad things about howard outweigh the good.

textAfterTable: Am learning a lot Since I'm in the School of Business the curriculum proved to be challenging. I took 15 credit hours for my first semester freshman year and I could handle it. There are hundreds of classes to take and what's better is that you can choose what classes you want and which teacher which is a choice that I didn't have in high school. I've learned the most in my Business Orientation class about credit and how to invest money at an earlier age. During the first semester, the School of B students are put into teams where we are given different projects and presentations that we have to present to the class. These groups helped me learn how to work with others and how to formulate certain business ideas and how to market new products. Now that my first semester is over, I'm excited to see how much Howard will teach me in the coming years.
